key_work.title: Spotlights: Tony Ayres
key_work.brief_description: A Portuguese Macau-born Australian showrunner, screenwriter, director in television and feature film. He is most notable for his films Walking on Water (2002) and The Home Song Stories (2007) as well his work in television.

end.title: Walking on Water
end.creator_credit: SBS Independent, Liz Watts and Tony Ayres
end.brief_description: An impressive Australian debut feature from Tony Ayres about a young man’s death and the aftermath for his friends and family.

links.description: After beginning his career producing narrative shorts and documentaries, Tony Ayres’ first feature Walking on Water debuted in 2002 and won five Australian Film Institute awards and a Teddy Award at Berlinale.

end.brief_description: Tom, now in his 40s, begins to write the memoirs of his 1960s childhood, as the little boy whose mother Rose was a glamorous Shanghai nightclub singer who met an Australian sailor and moved the family to Melbourne.

links.description: After Walking on Water, which followed two friends processing their grief after the death of a friend from AIDs, Ayres turned his attention to the autobiographical Home Song Stories, about his family’s migration to, and new life in, Australia.

end.title: The Family Law
end.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

constellations_primary.name: The Family Law
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of Asian representation on screens around the world that delves into TV, cinema, documentaries and Disney princesses.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

constellations_other.name: Tony Ayres
constellations_other.description: Charts the acclaimed career of Tony Ayres through his work in film and TV.

links.description: Home Song Stories is one of the few Australian films to explore the Asian Australian migrant experience and was groundbreaking for the Australian screen, as was The Family Law for the small screen. Ayres executive-produced the show based on Benjamin Law’s life.

end.brief_description: The Slap is an Australian television drama series based on the multi-award-winning novel by Australian author Christos Tsiolkas, which explores what happens when a man slaps a child, who is not related to him, at a suburban barbecue.

links.description: While Ayres didn’t direct episodes of The Family Law, he has worked in the TV industry for many years. One of the most acclaimed instances was The Slap, an adaptation of Christos Tsiolkas’s acclaimed novel about the social fabric of Melbourne.

end.brief_description: Seventeen talented Australian directors from diverse artistic disciplines each create a chapter of the hauntingly beautiful novel by Tim Winton. The overlapping stories explore the turning points in people’s lives in a stunning portrait of a small coastal community.

constellations_other.name: Canopy
constellations_other.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

links.description: Ayres was also involved in the adaptation of another beloved Australian book, Tim Winton’s The Turning. Like the episodic structure of The Slap, or chapters in a book, The Turning consisted of a series of shorts helmed by different directors.

end.title: The Bureau of Magical Things
end.brief_description: When ordinary teenager Kyra touches a mysterious book, she is transformed into a Tri-ling-–part-human, part-fairy and part-elf. In addition to acquiring amazing magical powers, Kyra discovers a secret world of magic all around her.

links.description: Kimie Tsukakoshi stars in the lead role of Kyra in The Bureau of Magical Things, after starring in The Family Law as Heidi Thomson.

end.title: Nowhere Boys
end.brief_description: Four teenage boys get lost in the forest and discover, when they return home, that they are in an alternate world identical to theirs except for one startling difference - they were never born.

links.description: Like The Bureau of Magical Things, Nowhere Boys is another hit Australian TV show that follows teenagers who have discovered they possess magical powers. It was created by none other than Tony Ayres.
